newsitem.title: BOSNIA: OSCE announces postponement of Bosnian polls.
newsitem.headline: OSCE announces postponement of Bosnian polls.

text.p: The head of the international mission organising Bosnia's post-war elections announced on Tuesday that local polls set for November would be postponed "due to continuing political problems".

Robert Frowick, chief of the Bosnia mission for the Organisation for Security and Cooperation in Europe (OSCE), confirmed earlier reports from diplomats when he told a news conference that the municipal elections should be held sometime next year.
An OSCE commission unanimously decided on Tuesday to delay the voting, Frowick said.
"As chairman of the commission I would urge that these critically important elections take place as soon as possible in 1997."
The move came a day after U.S. envoy John Kornblum met with Moslem, Croat and Serb leaders in the Bosnian capital Sarajevo to broker an agreement over the politically-sensitive municipal vote.
Bosnian Serb authorities, citing security concerns in villages where Moslems have resettled, had threatened to boycott the poll if the OSCE went ahead with it in November.
